title: 110_hr1044
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Disaster Response and Loan Improvements Act of 2007". Private disaster loans are addressed in the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new subsection on Private Disaster Loans, defining terms like 'disaster area' and 'eligible small business concern'. The Small Business Act of 1958 is amended to include a new subsection on Private Disaster Loans. A qualified private lender can issue loans to eligible small businesses in disaster areas, with the Administrator guaranteeing timely payment. The loans can be used for any purpose authorized under subsection (a) or (b), and an online application process may be established. The Administrator may coordinate with other federal agencies for additional assistance programs. Consultation with public and private sectors, including lenders, is required for establishing an online application process. Maximum amounts for guarantees are determined by the Administrator. The Administrator may guarantee up to 85% of a loan with a maximum amount of $2,000,000. The loan term can be up to 15 years without collateral and 25 years with collateral. No guarantee fee is collected, but an origination fee may be paid to a qualified private lender. A qualified private lender may charge an origination fee for a loan guaranteed by the Administrator. The lender can use its own loan documentation for the guaranteed loan. Implementation regulations for the Small Business Disaster Response and Loan Improvements Act of 2007 must be established within a year of enactment. The Small Business Disaster Response and Loan Improvements Act of 2007 requires the Administrator to establish permanent criteria for qualified private lenders and submit a progress report to Congress within 6 months of enactment. Authorization of appropriations is necessary to carry out this subsection. The Small Business Disaster Response and Loan Improvements Act of 2007 authorizes the Administrator to use appropriated funds to reduce interest rates by up to 3 percentage points for guaranteed loans. These amendments apply to disasters declared under the Small Business Act before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. The Small Business Disaster Response and Loan Improvements Act of 2007 authorizes the Administrator to reduce interest rates by up to 3 percentage points for guaranteed loans in disasters declared under the Small Business Act. Technical and conforming amendments are also included. The Small Business Act is amended to change references in sections 4(c) and 7(b) regarding interest rates on loans made under the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to change interest rates on loans made under the Act, specifying exceptions in subsections (c) and (d).
